consisting of right projective modules $P_i$ over the universal enveloping 
algebra $U(L)$, or infinity if no such finite resolution exists. Since for every
projective resolution (\ref{eq-resol}) and every $L$-module $M$, the cohomology
of the induced complex

of $L$-modules coincides with the Chevalley--Eilenberg cohomology 
${\operatorname{H}}^\bullet(L,M)$, $L$ has cohomological dimension $n$ if and only if there
is an $L$-module $M$ such that
${\operatorname{H}}^{n-1}(L,M) \ne 0$, and the two equivalent conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}[\upshape(i)]
\item
${\operatorname{H}}^i(L,M) = 0$ for any $L$-module $M$ and any $i \ge n$;
\item
${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,M) = 0$ for any $L$-module $M$.
\end{enumerate}

A similar notion may be defined for other classes of algebraic systems with good
cohomology theory, e.g., for groups and associative algebras. 

The Shapiro lemma about cohomology of a coinduced module implies that if $S$ is
a subalgebra of a Lie algebra $L$, then ${\operatorname{cd}}(S) \le {\operatorname{cd}}(L)$. As cohomological 
dimension of the one-dimensional Lie algebra is equal to one, the cohomological
dimension of any Lie algebra is $\ge 1$. In particular, the class of Lie 
algebras of cohomological dimension one is closed with respect to subalgebras.

Due to the standard interpretation of the second cohomology, the condition for
a Lie algebra $L$ to be of cohomological dimension 1 is equivalent to the 
condition that each exact sequence

nexttext:
of $L$-modules splits. The latter condition holds for a free Lie algebra, due to its universal 
property, and hence a free Lie algebra (of any rank) has cohomological dimension
one. The same is true for free groups and free associative algebras.

The celebrated Stallings--Swan theorem says that for groups the converse is 
true: a group of cohomological dimension one is free (cf., e.g., 
\cite{lecturenotes}). A question by Bourbaki 
(\cite[Chapitre II, \S 2, footnote to Exercice 9]{bourbaki}) asks whether 
the same is true for Lie algebras, i.e., whether a Lie algebra of 
cohomological dimension one is free.

For a while, it was widely believed that the answer to the latter question is 
affirmative (the author has witnessed several attempts of the proof), until 
Mikhalev, Umirbaev and Zolotykh constructed an example of a non-free Lie algebra
of cohomological dimension one over a field of characteristic $>2$ (cf. 
\cite{muz}; note that the cases of characteristic zero and characteristic $2$ 
remain widely open). This example is not a $p$-algebra, and at the same paper 
they made the following conjecture: a Lie $p$-algebra of cohomological dimension
one is a free Lie $p$-algebra (\cite[Conjecture 2]{muz}). As stated, the conjecture is somewhat misleading, 
for a free Lie $p$-algebra is not of cohomological dimension one: its 
cohomological dimension is equal to infinity. Indeed, for any element $x$ of 
such an algebra, the elements $x, x^{[p]}, x^{[p]^2}, \dots$ span an 
infinite-dimensional abelian subalgebra, whose cohomological dimension is equal
to infinity (cf. Lemma \ref{lemma-cd} below).

This conjecture may be repaired in two ways. First, one may merely ask about
description of Lie $p$-algebras of cohomological dimension one. A (trivial) 
answer to this question is given in \S \ref{sec-cd1}: such algebras are 
one-dimensional. Another possibility is to replace cohomological dimension with
\emph{restricted} cohomological dimension. The conjecture in this form is 
discussed in \S \ref{sec-p}. \S \ref{sec-cd1} also contains an auxiliary result
related to the old Jacobson conjecture about periodic Lie $p$-algebras.







\section{Lie $p$-algebras of cohomological dimension one, and almost-periodic algebras}\label{sec-cd1}

The following is elementary but useful.

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-cd}\hfill
\begin{enumerate}[\upshape(i)]
\item 
Cohomological dimension of an abelian Lie algebra is equal to its dimension.
\item
Cohomological dimension of the two-dimensional nonabelian Lie algebra is equal
to $2$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
It is clear that cohomological dimension of a Lie algebra does not exceed its
dimension.

(i)
For an abelian Lie algebra, we have ${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,K) = (\bigwedge^n L)^\star$ for
any $n$ ($^\star$ denotes the dual space).

(ii)
Let $L$ be a two-dimensional nonabelian Lie algebra with a basis $\{x,y\}$, 
$[x,y]=x$. For an one-dimensional module $Kv$ with an $L$-action
$x\bullet v = 0, y\bullet v = -v$, we have $\dim {\operatorname{H}}^2(L,Kv) = 1$.
\end{proof}


\begin{corollary}
A Lie algebra of cohomological dimension one does not contain a two-dimensional
subalgebra.
\end{corollary}

\begin{lemma}\label{cor-nilp}
Let $x,y$ be two elements of a Lie algebra without two-dimensional subalgebras,
such that $({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^n y = 0$ for some $n$. Then $x,y$ are linearly dependent.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Applying repeatedly the condition of absence of two dimensional subalgebras, we
can lower the degree $n$. Indeed, $({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^n y = [({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-1}(y),x] = 0$ 
implies $[({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-2}(y),x] = ({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-1}(y) = \lambda x$ for some $\lambda \in K$,
what, in turn, implies $\lambda = 0$. Repeating this process, we get eventually
$[y,x] = 0$, and hence $x,y$ are linearly dependent.
\end{proof}


\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-2dim}
A Lie $p$-algebra of dimension $>1$ over an algebraically closed field contains
a two-dimensional subalgebra.
\end{lemma}

This lemma may be considered as a generalization of an elementary fact that
a finite-dimensional Lie algebra of dimension $>1$ over an algebraically closed
field contains a two-dimensional subalgebra. We do not assume 
finite-dimensionality, but the presence of $p$-structure is a condition strong 
enough to infer the same conclusion.

\begin{proof}
Let $L$ be a Lie $p$-algebra without two-dimensional subalgebras. For any 
$x\in L$, we have $[x,x^{[p]}] = 0$, and hence
prevtext:

\begin{enumerate}[\upshape(i)]
\item
${\operatorname{H}}^i(L,M) = 0$ for any $L$-module $M$ and any $i \ge n$;
\item
${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,M) = 0$ for any $L$-module $M$.
\end{enumerate}

A similar notion may be defined for other classes of algebraic systems with good
cohomology theory, e.g., for groups and associative algebras. 

The Shapiro lemma about cohomology of a coinduced module implies that if $S$ is
a subalgebra of a Lie algebra $L$, then ${\operatorname{cd}}(S) \le {\operatorname{cd}}(L)$. As cohomological 
dimension of the one-dimensional Lie algebra is equal to one, the cohomological
dimension of any Lie algebra is $\ge 1$. In particular, the class of Lie 
algebras of cohomological dimension one is closed with respect to subalgebras.

Due to the standard interpretation of the second cohomology, the condition for
a Lie algebra $L$ to be of cohomological dimension 1 is equivalent to the 
condition that each exact sequence

nexttext:
for some $\lambda(x) \in K$. 

If $\lambda(x)$ is a constant, then $L$ is abelian
by \cite[Chapter V, Exercise 15]{jacobson}, and hence is one-dimensional. The 
general case, however, requires a bit of extra work. We pause the proof of 
Lemma \ref{lemma-2dim} for a moment to reflect on the condition (\ref{eq-p1}).
This condition reminds of various conditions on the $p$-map studied by Jacobson
and others. The major open problem in this area is the conjecture of Jacobson 
that a periodic Lie $p$-algebra is abelian (cf. 
\cite[Chapter V, Exercise 16]{jacobson}). Recall that a Lie algebra $L$ is 
called \emph{periodic} if for any $x\in L$ there is integer $n(x)>0$ such that 
$x^{[p]^{n(x)}} = x$. The strongest result toward this conjecture belongs to 
Premet: a periodic \emph{finite-dimensional} Lie algebra is abelian 
(\cite[Corollary 1]{premet}).

Generalizing the condition of periodicity, let us call a Lie $p$-algebra $L$
\emph{almost periodic}, if for any $x\in L$, there is an integer $n(x)>0$ and
an element $\lambda(x) \in K$ such that

of $L$-modules splits. The latter condition holds for a free Lie algebra, due to its universal 
property, and hence a free Lie algebra (of any rank) has cohomological dimension
one. The same is true for free groups and free associative algebras.

The celebrated Stallings--Swan theorem says that for groups the converse is 
true: a group of cohomological dimension one is free (cf., e.g., 
\cite{lecturenotes}). A question by Bourbaki 
(\cite[Chapitre II, \S 2, footnote to Exercice 9]{bourbaki}) asks whether 
the same is true for Lie algebras, i.e., whether a Lie algebra of 
cohomological dimension one is free.

For a while, it was widely believed that the answer to the latter question is 
affirmative (the author has witnessed several attempts of the proof), until

of cohomological dimension one over a field of characteristic $>2$ (cf. 
\cite{muz}; note that the cases of characteristic zero and characteristic $2$ 
remain widely open). This example is not a $p$-algebra, and at the same paper 
they made the following conjecture: a Lie $p$-algebra of cohomological dimension
one is a free Lie $p$-algebra (\cite[Conjecture 2]{muz}). As stated, the conjecture is somewhat misleading, 
for a free Lie $p$-algebra is not of cohomological dimension one: its 
cohomological dimension is equal to infinity. Indeed, for any element $x$ of 
such an algebra, the elements $x, x^{[p]}, x^{[p]^2}, \dots$ span an 
infinite-dimensional abelian subalgebra, whose cohomological dimension is equal
to infinity (cf. Lemma \ref{lemma-cd} below).

This conjecture may be repaired in two ways. First, one may merely ask about
description of Lie $p$-algebras of cohomological dimension one. A (trivial) 
answer to this question is given in \S \ref{sec-cd1}: such algebras are 
one-dimensional. Another possibility is to replace cohomological dimension with
\emph{restricted} cohomological dimension. The conjecture in this form is 
discussed in \S \ref{sec-p}. \S \ref{sec-cd1} also contains an auxiliary result
related to the old Jacobson conjecture about periodic Lie $p$-algebras.







\section{Lie $p$-algebras of cohomological dimension one, and almost-periodic algebras}\label{sec-cd1}

The following is elementary but useful.

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-cd}\hfill
\begin{enumerate}[\upshape(i)]
\item 
Cohomological dimension of an abelian Lie algebra is equal to its dimension.
\item
Cohomological dimension of the two-dimensional nonabelian Lie algebra is equal
to $2$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
It is clear that cohomological dimension of a Lie algebra does not exceed its
dimension.

(i)
For an abelian Lie algebra, we have ${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,K) = (\bigwedge^n L)^\star$ for
any $n$ ($^\star$ denotes the dual space).

(ii)
Let $L$ be a two-dimensional nonabelian Lie algebra with a basis $\{x,y\}$, 
$[x,y]=x$. For an one-dimensional module $Kv$ with an $L$-action
$x\bullet v = 0, y\bullet v = -v$, we have $\dim {\operatorname{H}}^2(L,Kv) = 1$.
\end{proof}


\begin{corollary}
A Lie algebra of cohomological dimension one does not contain a two-dimensional
subalgebra.
\end{corollary}

\begin{lemma}\label{cor-nilp}
Let $x,y$ be two elements of a Lie algebra without two-dimensional subalgebras,
such that $({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^n y = 0$ for some $n$. Then $x,y$ are linearly dependent.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Applying repeatedly the condition of absence of two dimensional subalgebras, we
can lower the degree $n$. Indeed, $({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^n y = [({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-1}(y),x] = 0$ 
implies $[({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-2}(y),x] = ({\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}} x)^{n-1}(y) = \lambda x$ for some $\lambda \in K$,
what, in turn, implies $\lambda = 0$. Repeating this process, we get eventually
$[y,x] = 0$, and hence $x,y$ are linearly dependent.
\end{proof}


\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-2dim}
A Lie $p$-algebra of dimension $>1$ over an algebraically closed field contains
a two-dimensional subalgebra.
\end{lemma}

This lemma may be considered as a generalization of an elementary fact that
a finite-dimensional Lie algebra of dimension $>1$ over an algebraically closed
field contains a two-dimensional subalgebra. We do not assume 
finite-dimensionality, but the presence of $p$-structure is a condition strong 
enough to infer the same conclusion.

\begin{proof}
Let $L$ be a Lie $p$-algebra without two-dimensional subalgebras. For any 
$x\in L$, we have $[x,x^{[p]}] = 0$, and hence

nexttext:
The elements for which $\lambda(x) = 0$, i.e., $x^{[p]^{n(x)}} = 0$, will be 
called \emph{$p$-nilpotent}.

\begin{lemma}\label{prop-jacobson}
Let $L$ be an almost periodic Lie $p$-algebra of dimension $>1$ over an 
algebraically closed field, with all $n(x)$'s bounded. Then $L$ contains a 
nonzero $p$-nilpotent element.
\end{lemma}

Note some other related results connecting properties of Lie ($p$-)algebras and
its elements: Chwe proved in \cite{chwe} that a Lie $p$-algebra over an 
algebraically closed field with a nondegenerate $p$-map is abelian. Farnsteiner 
investigated in \cite{farns-semilin} Lie $p$-algebras in which a certain power 
$[p]^n$ of the $p$-map is $p^n$-semilinear. 



The condition (\ref{eq-x-th}) is somewhat reminiscent of semilinearity (in some sense stronger, in some sense weaker). Finally, it is
well-known that any finite-dimensional Lie algebra over an algebraically closed
field contains a nilpotent element. (For Lie $p$-algebras, this follows from 
the Jordan--Chevalley decomposition, cf., e.g., 
\cite[Proof of Theorem 3]{premet}, and for a short elementary proof valid for
arbitrary Lie algebras, cf. \cite{benkart-isaacs}). Lemma \ref{prop-jacobson}
establishes a similar result for not necessary finite-dimensional Lie algebras,
but subject to a strong condition of bounded $p$-periodicity.

Since $n(x)$ are bounded, we may assume that

If $\lambda(x)$ is a constant, then $L$ is abelian

general case, however, requires a bit of extra work. We pause the proof of

This condition reminds of various conditions on the $p$-map studied by Jacobson

$x^{[p]^{n(x)}} = x$. The strongest result toward this conjecture belongs to

(\cite[Corollary 1]{premet}).

Generalizing the condition of periodicity, let us call a Lie $p$-algebra $L$
\emph{almost periodic}, if for any $x\in L$, there is an integer $n(x)>0$ and
an element $\lambda(x) \in K$ such that

Jacobson binomial formula for the $p$-map (strictly speaking, its

The elements for which $\lambda(x) = 0$, i.e., $x^{[p]^{n(x)}} = 0$, will be 
called \emph{$p$-nilpotent}.

\begin{lemma}\label{prop-jacobson}
Let $L$ be an almost periodic Lie $p$-algebra of dimension $>1$ over an 
algebraically closed field, with all $n(x)$'s bounded. Then $L$ contains a 
nonzero $p$-nilpotent element.
\end{lemma}

Note some other related results connecting properties of Lie ($p$-)algebras and
its elements: Chwe proved in \cite{chwe} that a Lie $p$-algebra over an 
algebraically closed field with a nondegenerate $p$-map is abelian. Farnsteiner 
investigated in \cite{farns-semilin} Lie $p$-algebras in which a certain power 
$[p]^n$ of the $p$-map is $p^n$-semilinear. 



The condition (\ref{eq-x-th}) is somewhat reminiscent of semilinearity (in some sense stronger, in some sense weaker). Finally, it is
well-known that any finite-dimensional Lie algebra over an algebraically closed
field contains a nilpotent element. (For Lie $p$-algebras, this follows from 
the Jordan--Chevalley decomposition, cf., e.g., 
\cite[Proof of Theorem 3]{premet}, and for a short elementary proof valid for
arbitrary Lie algebras, cf. \cite{benkart-isaacs}). Lemma \ref{prop-jacobson}
establishes a similar result for not necessary finite-dimensional Lie algebras,
but subject to a strong condition of bounded $p$-periodicity.

\begin{proof}[Proof of Lemma \ref{prop-jacobson}]
Since $n(x)$ are bounded, we may assume that

nexttext:
where $s_i(x,y)$ are certain Lie monomials in $x,y$. Completing $x,y$ to a basis
of $L$, writing $s_i(x,y)$'s as linear combinations of basis elements, and 
collecting all coefficients of $x$ in (\ref{eq-pn}), we get that 
$\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is a polynomial in $t$ with the free term $\lambda(x)$.

Suppose that there is a pair $x,y$ such that $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is not constant. 
Since the ground field $K$ is algebraically closed, $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ has a
root $\xi$. This means that the nonzero element $x + \xi y$ is nilpotent.

Suppose now that for any pair $x,y\in L$, $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is constant, i.e.,
$\varphi_{xy}(t) = \lambda(x)$. This means that $\lambda(x + ty) = \lambda(x)$ 
for any linearly independent $x,y\in L$, and any $t\in K$, and, consequently, 
$\lambda(x) = \lambda$ is constant. If $\lambda \ne 0$, then substituting in 
(\ref{eq-x}) $\alpha x$ instead of $x$, we get that $\alpha^{p^n-1} = \alpha$ 
for any $\alpha \in K$, i.e., $K$ is a finite field, a contradiction. Hence 
$\lambda = 0$, and every element of $L$ is nilpotent. 
\end{proof}


\noindent\textit{Continuation of the proof of Lemma \ref{lemma-2dim}}.
According to Lemma \ref{prop-jacobson} (with $n(x) = 1$ for all $x$), $L$
is either one-dimensional, or contains a nonzero nilpotent element. In the 
latter case by Lemma \ref{cor-nilp}, $L$ is one-dimensional too, a 
contradiction.
\end{proof}


\begin{theorem}
A Lie $p$-algebra of cohomological dimension one is one-dimensional.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
As the property of being a $p$-algebra, and dimension (and, in particular, 
vanishing) of cohomology do not change under field extensions, we may assume 
that the ground field is algebraically closed. Then the claim follows from 
Corollary to Lemma \ref{lemma-cd}, and Lemma \ref{lemma-2dim}.
\end{proof}







\section{Lie $p$-algebras of restricted cohomological dimension one}\label{sec-p}

When speaking about cohomological dimension, we consider the category of 
\emph{all} Lie algebra modules, including infinite-dimensional ones. If we 
restrict ourselves with, say, finite-dimensional Lie algebras and the category 
of finite-dimensional modules, the whole subject, both in results and methods 
employed, becomes quite different. In fact, we cannot longer speak about 
cohomological dimension, as vanishing of all cohomology in a given degree does 
not imply vanishing in higher degrees. A sample of results in this domain: in 
characteristic zero, an ``almost'' converse of the classical Whitehead Lemmas 
holds (\cite{z1}, \cite{z2}), and in positive characteristic, for any degree 
less than the dimension of the algebra, a module with non-vanishing cohomology 
exists (\cite{dzhu} and \cite{fs}).

Still, instead of the category of all modules we can consider a smaller 
subcategory of modules with a good-behaving cohomology theory: for example, 
restricted modules with restricted cohomology. The definition of a 
\emph{restricted cohomological dimension} of a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ over a field
of positive characteristic (notation: ${\operatorname{cd}}_*(L)$) repeats the definition of the ordinary 
cohomological dimension, with projective resolutions (\ref{eq-resol}) are 
considered in the category of restricted modules over the restricted universal 
enveloping algebra $u(L)$.

As in the unrestricted case, Shapiro's lemma for restricted cohomology implies
that the restricted cohomological dimension does not increase when passing to
subalgebras. In particular, the class of Lie $p$-algebras of restricted 
cohomological dimension one is closed with respect to subalgebras. A free Lie
$p$-algebra has restricted cohomological dimension one. In this context, we
reformulate the Conjecture $2$ from \cite{muz}:

\begin{conjecture}
A Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one is a free Lie
$p$-algebra.
\end{conjecture}

Let us establish some facts about Lie $p$-algebras of restricted cohomological
dimension one, which provide some evidence in support of this conjecture.

The following fact was established in \cite[Theorem 5.1]{chwe-tams} using a
not entirely trivial result from homological algebra due to Kaplansky. We give 
an alternative, more elementary proof --  a mere reformulation of known (and 
easy) results about (co)homology of commutative associative algebras.

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-fin}
A finite-dimensional Lie $p$-algebra has infinite restricted cohomological 
dimension.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
As for a Lie $p$-algebra $L$, and an $u(L)$-bimodule $M$, we have

for some fixed $n$ (for example, by letting $n$ to be the product of all

Pick any two linearly independent elements $x,y\in L$, and set $\varphi_{xy}(t) = \lambda(x + ty)$, for $t\in K$. Using the well-known 
Jacobson binomial formula for the $p$-map (strictly speaking, its 
generalization for the $n$th power of the $p$-map -- cf., e.g., 
\cite[\S 1]{farns-semilin}), we have

nexttext:
where ${\operatorname{H}}_*$ and ${\operatorname{HH}}$ stand for the restricted cohomology of a Lie 
$p$-algebra, and Hochschild cohomology of an associative algebra, respectively,
and $M^{{\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}}}$ is a restricted $L$-module structure on $M$ defined via 
$x \bullet m = xm - mx$ for $x\in L$, $m \in M$, it is enough, for each 
finite-dimensional $L$, to exhibit an $u(L)$-bimodule in which Hochschild 
cohomology does not vanish for an arbitrarily high degree.

Also, it is enough to prove the claim for an one-generated (abelian) Lie 
$p$-algebra, i.e., for a Lie algebra $L$ with a basis of the form 
$\{x, x^{[p]}, x^{[p]^2}, \dots, x^{[p]^{n-1}}\}$, where an element $x$ 
satisfies the relation of the form
prevtext:
where $s_i(x,y)$ are certain Lie monomials in $x,y$. Completing $x,y$ to a basis
of $L$, writing $s_i(x,y)$'s as linear combinations of basis elements, and 
collecting all coefficients of $x$ in (\ref{eq-pn}), we get that 
$\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is a polynomial in $t$ with the free term $\lambda(x)$.

Suppose that there is a pair $x,y$ such that $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is not constant. 
Since the ground field $K$ is algebraically closed, $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ has a
root $\xi$. This means that the nonzero element $x + \xi y$ is nilpotent.

Suppose now that for any pair $x,y\in L$, $\varphi_{xy}(t)$ is constant, i.e.,
$\varphi_{xy}(t) = \lambda(x)$. This means that $\lambda(x + ty) = \lambda(x)$ 
for any linearly independent $x,y\in L$, and any $t\in K$, and, consequently, 
$\lambda(x) = \lambda$ is constant. If $\lambda \ne 0$, then substituting in 
(\ref{eq-x}) $\alpha x$ instead of $x$, we get that $\alpha^{p^n-1} = \alpha$ 
for any $\alpha \in K$, i.e., $K$ is a finite field, a contradiction. Hence 
$\lambda = 0$, and every element of $L$ is nilpotent. 
\end{proof}


\noindent\textit{Continuation of the proof of Lemma \ref{lemma-2dim}}.
According to Lemma \ref{prop-jacobson} (with $n(x) = 1$ for all $x$), $L$
is either one-dimensional, or contains a nonzero nilpotent element. In the 
latter case by Lemma \ref{cor-nilp}, $L$ is one-dimensional too, a 
contradiction.
\end{proof}


\begin{theorem}
A Lie $p$-algebra of cohomological dimension one is one-dimensional.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
As the property of being a $p$-algebra, and dimension (and, in particular, 
vanishing) of cohomology do not change under field extensions, we may assume 
that the ground field is algebraically closed. Then the claim follows from 
Corollary to Lemma \ref{lemma-cd}, and Lemma \ref{lemma-2dim}.
\end{proof}







\section{Lie $p$-algebras of restricted cohomological dimension one}\label{sec-p}

When speaking about cohomological dimension, we consider the category of 
\emph{all} Lie algebra modules, including infinite-dimensional ones. If we 
restrict ourselves with, say, finite-dimensional Lie algebras and the category 
of finite-dimensional modules, the whole subject, both in results and methods 
employed, becomes quite different. In fact, we cannot longer speak about 
cohomological dimension, as vanishing of all cohomology in a given degree does 
not imply vanishing in higher degrees. A sample of results in this domain: in 
characteristic zero, an ``almost'' converse of the classical Whitehead Lemmas 
holds (\cite{z1}, \cite{z2}), and in positive characteristic, for any degree 
less than the dimension of the algebra, a module with non-vanishing cohomology 
exists (\cite{dzhu} and \cite{fs}).

Still, instead of the category of all modules we can consider a smaller 
subcategory of modules with a good-behaving cohomology theory: for example, 
restricted modules with restricted cohomology. The definition of a 
\emph{restricted cohomological dimension} of a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ over a field
of positive characteristic (notation: ${\operatorname{cd}}_*(L)$) repeats the definition of the ordinary 
cohomological dimension, with projective resolutions (\ref{eq-resol}) are 
considered in the category of restricted modules over the restricted universal 
enveloping algebra $u(L)$.

As in the unrestricted case, Shapiro's lemma for restricted cohomology implies
that the restricted cohomological dimension does not increase when passing to
subalgebras. In particular, the class of Lie $p$-algebras of restricted 
cohomological dimension one is closed with respect to subalgebras. A free Lie
$p$-algebra has restricted cohomological dimension one. In this context, we
reformulate the Conjecture $2$ from \cite{muz}:

\begin{conjecture}
A Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one is a free Lie
$p$-algebra.
\end{conjecture}

Let us establish some facts about Lie $p$-algebras of restricted cohomological
dimension one, which provide some evidence in support of this conjecture.

The following fact was established in \cite[Theorem 5.1]{chwe-tams} using a
not entirely trivial result from homological algebra due to Kaplansky. We give 
an alternative, more elementary proof --  a mere reformulation of known (and 
easy) results about (co)homology of commutative associative algebras.

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma-fin}
A finite-dimensional Lie $p$-algebra has infinite restricted cohomological 
dimension.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
As for a Lie $p$-algebra $L$, and an $u(L)$-bimodule $M$, we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\operatorname{H}}^{n}_{*}(L,M^{{\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}}})\simeq{%
\operatorname{HH}}^{n}(u(L),M)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mo>*</mo><mi>n</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>M</mi><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝖺𝖽</mi></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>H</mi><mi>n</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
for $\lambda_i \in K$, $\lambda_n \ne 0$. In this case $u(L) \simeq K[x]/(f)$, 
where the polynomial $f$ is obtained from the left-hand side of (\ref{eq-f}) by 
replacing $[p]$-powers in a Lie $p$-algebra by the ordinary $p$-powers in a
polynomial algebra: 
$f(t) = \lambda_0 + \lambda_1 t^p + \dots + \lambda_n t^{p^n}$. 

The Hochschild cohomology of associative algebras of the form $K[x]/(f)$ was
well studied in the literature. For example, in \cite[Proposition 2.2]{holm} a 
periodic free resolution of such algebras is constructed, and it is proved that
the Hochschild cohomology ${\operatorname{HH}}^n(K[x]/(f), K[x]/(f))$, for any $f$, does not 
vanish for an arbitrarily high $n$. As $K[x]/(f)$ is commutative, 
$K[x]/(f)^{{\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}}}$, as an $L$-module, is the direct sum of $p^n$ copies of the 
trivial $L$-module $K$, and due to isomorphism (\ref{eq-isom}), 
${\operatorname{H}}^n_*(L,K)$ is nonzero for an arbitrarily high $n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}\label{prop-1}
A $p$-subalgebra of a Lie $p$-algebra of finite restricted cohomological 
dimension is infinite-dimensional.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Follows from Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}.
\end{proof}

In particular, in a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ of finite restricted cohomological 
dimension every nonzero element $x$ is not $p$-algebraic, i.e., does not satisfy
any relation of the form (\ref{eq-f}) (or, in other words, the $p$-envelope of 
$x$ inside $L$ is infinite-dimensional). This is a Lie-$p$-algebraic analog of 
the well-known fact that groups of finite cohomological dimension are torsion-free (cf., 
e.g., \cite[p.~6, Corollary 2]{lecturenotes}).

\bigskip

Similarly with the unrestricted case, we have:

\begin{corollary}
The restricted cohomological dimension of any Lie $p$-algebra is $\ge 1$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
Take an arbitrary nonzero element $x$ in a Lie $p$-algebra $L$. If $x$ is 
$p$-algebraic, then by Proposition \ref{prop-1}, $L$ has infinite restricted 
cohomological dimension. If $x$ is not $p$-algebraic, then it generates a free 
Lie $p$-subalgebra of rank $1$. The restricted cohomological dimension of the 
latter algebra is equal to $1$, and hence the restricted cohomological dimension
of $L$ is $\ge 1$.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
An abelian $p$-subalgebra of a Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological
dimension one is isomorphic to the free Lie $p$-algebra of rank one.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
It is enough to prove that any two commuting elements, $x$ and $y$, in a Lie 
$p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one, can be represented 
as $p$-polynomials of a third element. Suppose the contrary. By 
Proposition \ref{prop-1}, each of $x$, $y$ generate the free Lie $p$-algebra of
rank one, and hence the restricted universal enveloping algebra of the 
$p$-subalgebra $S$ of $L$ generated by $x,y$, is isomorphic to the polynomial 
algebra in two variables $K[x,y]$. The latter algebra has non-vanishing 2nd 
Hochschild cohomology (for example, 
${\operatorname{HH}}^2(K[x,y],K[x,y]) \simeq \bigwedge^2 ({\operatorname{Der}}(K[x,y])) \otimes_{K[x,y]} K$ by 
the Hochschild--Kostant--Rosenberg theorem), and reasoning as in the end of the
proof of Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}, we get that ${\operatorname{H}}^2_*(S,K)$ does not vanish, 
whence ${\operatorname{cd}}_*(L) \ge 2$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}


The next lemma shows that the (ordinary) cohomology of Lie $p$-algebras of 
restricted cohomological dimension one behaves in a rather peculiar way.

\begin{lemma}\label{prop-3}
Let $L$ be a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one, and
$M$ a restricted $L$-module $M$. Then
prevtext:

$p$-algebra, and Hochschild cohomology of an associative algebra, respectively,
and $M^{{\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}}}$ is a restricted $L$-module structure on $M$ defined via 
$x \bullet m = xm - mx$ for $x\in L$, $m \in M$, it is enough, for each 
finite-dimensional $L$, to exhibit an $u(L)$-bimodule in which Hochschild 
cohomology does not vanish for an arbitrarily high degree.

Also, it is enough to prove the claim for an one-generated (abelian) Lie 
$p$-algebra, i.e., for a Lie algebra $L$ with a basis of the form 
$\{x, x^{[p]}, x^{[p]^2}, \dots, x^{[p]^{n-1}}\}$, where an element $x$ 
satisfies the relation of the form

for $\lambda_i \in K$, $\lambda_n \ne 0$. In this case $u(L) \simeq K[x]/(f)$, 
where the polynomial $f$ is obtained from the left-hand side of (\ref{eq-f}) by 
replacing $[p]$-powers in a Lie $p$-algebra by the ordinary $p$-powers in a
polynomial algebra: 
$f(t) = \lambda_0 + \lambda_1 t^p + \dots + \lambda_n t^{p^n}$. 

The Hochschild cohomology of associative algebras of the form $K[x]/(f)$ was
well studied in the literature. For example, in \cite[Proposition 2.2]{holm} a 
periodic free resolution of such algebras is constructed, and it is proved that
the Hochschild cohomology ${\operatorname{HH}}^n(K[x]/(f), K[x]/(f))$, for any $f$, does not 
vanish for an arbitrarily high $n$. As $K[x]/(f)$ is commutative, 
$K[x]/(f)^{{\operatorname{\mathsf{ad}}}}$, as an $L$-module, is the direct sum of $p^n$ copies of the 
trivial $L$-module $K$, and due to isomorphism (\ref{eq-isom}), 
${\operatorname{H}}^n_*(L,K)$ is nonzero for an arbitrarily high $n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}\label{prop-1}
A $p$-subalgebra of a Lie $p$-algebra of finite restricted cohomological 
dimension is infinite-dimensional.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Follows from Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}.
\end{proof}

In particular, in a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ of finite restricted cohomological 
dimension every nonzero element $x$ is not $p$-algebraic, i.e., does not satisfy
any relation of the form (\ref{eq-f}) (or, in other words, the $p$-envelope of 
$x$ inside $L$ is infinite-dimensional). This is a Lie-$p$-algebraic analog of 
the well-known fact that groups of finite cohomological dimension are torsion-free (cf., 
e.g., \cite[p.~6, Corollary 2]{lecturenotes}).

\bigskip

Similarly with the unrestricted case, we have:

\begin{corollary}
The restricted cohomological dimension of any Lie $p$-algebra is $\ge 1$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
Take an arbitrary nonzero element $x$ in a Lie $p$-algebra $L$. If $x$ is 
$p$-algebraic, then by Proposition \ref{prop-1}, $L$ has infinite restricted 
cohomological dimension. If $x$ is not $p$-algebraic, then it generates a free 
Lie $p$-subalgebra of rank $1$. The restricted cohomological dimension of the 
latter algebra is equal to $1$, and hence the restricted cohomological dimension
of $L$ is $\ge 1$.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
An abelian $p$-subalgebra of a Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological
dimension one is isomorphic to the free Lie $p$-algebra of rank one.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
It is enough to prove that any two commuting elements, $x$ and $y$, in a Lie 
$p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one, can be represented 
as $p$-polynomials of a third element. Suppose the contrary. By 
Proposition \ref{prop-1}, each of $x$, $y$ generate the free Lie $p$-algebra of
rank one, and hence the restricted universal enveloping algebra of the 
$p$-subalgebra $S$ of $L$ generated by $x,y$, is isomorphic to the polynomial 
algebra in two variables $K[x,y]$. The latter algebra has non-vanishing 2nd 
Hochschild cohomology (for example, 
${\operatorname{HH}}^2(K[x,y],K[x,y]) \simeq \bigwedge^2 ({\operatorname{Der}}(K[x,y])) \otimes_{K[x,y]} K$ by 
the Hochschild--Kostant--Rosenberg theorem), and reasoning as in the end of the
proof of Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}, we get that ${\operatorname{H}}^2_*(S,K)$ does not vanish, 
whence ${\operatorname{cd}}_*(L) \ge 2$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}


The next lemma shows that the (ordinary) cohomology of Lie $p$-algebras of 
restricted cohomological dimension one behaves in a rather peculiar way.

\begin{lemma}\label{prop-3}
Let $L$ be a Lie $p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one, and
$M$ a restricted $L$-module $M$. Then

nexttext:
abutting to ${\operatorname{H}}^{s+t}(L,M)$ (cf. \cite[Proposition 5.3]{fp}; note that the 
standing assumption in \cite{fp} of finite-dimensionality of algebras and 
modules is not relevant here; cf. also \cite[Theorem 4.1]{farns-coho} and 
\cite[Corollary 1.3]{muzere}). Here 
${\operatorname{C}}^n(V,W) \simeq (\bigwedge^n V)^\star \otimes W$ denotes, as usual, the space
of skew-symmetric $n$-linear maps from one vector space to another.

If ${\operatorname{H}}^s_*(L,M) = 0$ for $s \ge 2$, the only nonvanishing ${\operatorname{E}}_2$ terms are
${\operatorname{E}}_2^{0t}$ and ${\operatorname{E}}_2^{1t}$. Hence the spectral sequence stabilizes at ${\operatorname{E}}_2$, 
${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,M) \simeq {\operatorname{E}}_2^{0n} \oplus {\operatorname{E}}_2^{1,n-1}$ for any $n \ge 1$, and 
(\ref{eq-ss}) follows.
\end{proof}

Lemma \ref{prop-3} provides a yet another proof of the fact that a Lie 
$p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one is 
infinite-dimensional (a particular case of Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}), without 
appealing to any computation of Hochschild cohomology. Indeed, suppose the 
contrary, and take in (\ref{eq-ss}) $n = \dim L + 1$. Then the left-hand side 
and the first direct summand at the right-hand side of the isomorphism vanish, 
and the second direct summand is isomorphic to ${\operatorname{H}}^1_*(L,M)$. Therefore, 
${\operatorname{H}}^1_*(L,M) = 0$ for any restricted $L$-module $M$, i.e., $L$ is of 
restricted cohomological dimension zero, a contradiction.

Moreover, a stronger statement holds:

\begin{proposition}
A Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one has infinite 
(ordinary) cohomological dimension.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $L$ be a Lie algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one. Taking in 
(\ref{eq-ss}) $M=K$, we get

\operatorname{H}}^{s}_{*}(L,M)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>C</mi><mi>t</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mo>*</mo><mi>s</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><msup><mo largeop="true" mathsize="160%" stretchy="false" symmetric="true">⋀</mo><mi>n</mi></msup><mi>L</mi></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⋆</mo></msup><mo>⊗</mo><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\operatorname</mtext></merror></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mo>*</mo><mi>s</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Either by Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}, or by the reasoning above, $L$ is 
infinite-dimensional, and thus $\bigwedge^n L$, and hence ${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,K)$, does 
not vanish for any $n \ge 1$.
\end{proof}

prevtext:
abutting to ${\operatorname{H}}^{s+t}(L,M)$ (cf. \cite[Proposition 5.3]{fp}; note that the 
standing assumption in \cite{fp} of finite-dimensionality of algebras and 
modules is not relevant here; cf. also \cite[Theorem 4.1]{farns-coho} and 
\cite[Corollary 1.3]{muzere}). Here 
${\operatorname{C}}^n(V,W) \simeq (\bigwedge^n V)^\star \otimes W$ denotes, as usual, the space
of skew-symmetric $n$-linear maps from one vector space to another.

If ${\operatorname{H}}^s_*(L,M) = 0$ for $s \ge 2$, the only nonvanishing ${\operatorname{E}}_2$ terms are
${\operatorname{E}}_2^{0t}$ and ${\operatorname{E}}_2^{1t}$. Hence the spectral sequence stabilizes at ${\operatorname{E}}_2$, 
${\operatorname{H}}^n(L,M) \simeq {\operatorname{E}}_2^{0n} \oplus {\operatorname{E}}_2^{1,n-1}$ for any $n \ge 1$, and 
(\ref{eq-ss}) follows.
\end{proof}

Lemma \ref{prop-3} provides a yet another proof of the fact that a Lie 
$p$-algebra $L$ of restricted cohomological dimension one is 
infinite-dimensional (a particular case of Lemma \ref{lemma-fin}), without 
appealing to any computation of Hochschild cohomology. Indeed, suppose the 
contrary, and take in (\ref{eq-ss}) $n = \dim L + 1$. Then the left-hand side 
and the first direct summand at the right-hand side of the isomorphism vanish, 
and the second direct summand is isomorphic to ${\operatorname{H}}^1_*(L,M)$. Therefore, 
${\operatorname{H}}^1_*(L,M) = 0$ for any restricted $L$-module $M$, i.e., $L$ is of 
restricted cohomological dimension zero, a contradiction.

Moreover, a stronger statement holds:

\begin{proposition}
A Lie $p$-algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one has infinite 
(ordinary) cohomological dimension.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $L$ be a Lie algebra of restricted cohomological dimension one. Taking in 
(\ref{eq-ss}) $M=K$, we get
